title: Before 1 January 2020, will Velodyne announce the release of a LiDAR unit with a maximum range of 400 meters or more?
preds: Before 1 January 2020, will Velodyne announce the release of a LiDAR unit with a maximum range of 400 meters or more? Lack of motivation and no conferences to support such an announcement are left this year.
Cost, cost, cost are three very important factors in a LIDAR system. All efforts should be focused here, not on range.

Velodyne is doing the smart(!) thing and focusing on midmarket (cost effective) products. 120 meters and 40 degree vertical field. 400 meters will happen, challenging in this timeline, however.
https://www.greencarcongress.com/2019/08/20190810-velodyne.html

They're still hiring engineers. I just don't think they'll get this to market that quick. They'll be a lot better off if they focus on the drones market, wipe up some profits there, and then move into the much riskier automotive sector. By then, their new hires will have time to address automotive safety. Velodyne themselves is predicting it might be in Tesla vehicles "next year" (see second link.) This whole self driving concept is a much slower process than many continue to hope, and to hype. This technology is further away than that.
https://www.marketwatch.com/press-release/lidar-drones-market-2019-size-share-scope-growth-opportunities-analysis-by-dji-sick-sensor-intelligence-3d-robotics-velodyne-lidar-incwaymo-teledyne-optech-riegl-hexagon-and-others-2019-05-13
https://www.marketbeat.com/articles/insider-qa-velodyne-advocates-for-safer-self-driving-cars-2019-05-19/
https://www.wired.com/story/lidar-cheap-make-self-driving-reality/

Coming down further, it looks to me that Velodyne is focused on software solutions more than extending max range on their hardware. "Velodyne Lidar, Inc. today announced it has acquired mapping and localization software as well as intellectual property assets from Mapper.ai. Mapper technology will enable Velodyne to accelerate development of Vella™, breakthrough software that establishes its directional view Velarray™ lidar sensor. The Velarray is the first solid-state Velodyne lidar sensor that is embeddable and fits behind a windshield, as an integral component for superior, more effective advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS)." https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20190723005257/en/

This isn’t necessarily going to help you forecast but may put pressure on Velodyne to do “something”:
https://www.wired.com/story/lidar-cheap-make-self-driving-reality/

Velodyne uses the 905 nm wavelength in its LiDAR's and has not announced any plans to deviate from its wavelength. Since the human eye is sensitive at this wavelength, transmission power is legally limited to avoid any health impacts. Without major innovations on capitalizing on the limited intensity level, it is difficult to foresee a Velodyne LiDAR with a maximum range of 400m within so short a timescale.
Good enough is good enough, next feature to consider is what  - - cost?

Strikes me as a classic question of trade-offs: good, cheap or fast. Choose two.  In order for lidar to be used in automobiles, the cost and size has to come down. If that's your focus, then it is difficult to also increase your range at the same time. Further, they already have an industry leading 300m.
They better get it done soon , because that guy on auto pilot going through Montana right now is sleeping and there is a jack knifed semi up ahead
Some more evidence that they're focusing on cost-reduction instead of advancing capabilities: https://www.therobotreport.com/velodyne-lidar-partners-with-nikon-to-mass-produce-cheaper-lidar-sensors/
What is the incentive? Cost, cost, and cost are the three most important features to work on.

300 meter max right now. 400 is not much of a stretch from 300 but I don't think they will find it neccessary to go to 400m yet, probably more like late 2020 for the 2021 model.  https://www.forbes.com/sites/alanohnsman/2019/03/22/velodynes-godfather-of-laser-sensors-hits-500-million-milestone-sets-his-sights-on-safer-self-driving-cars/#36e3394f6035

Increasing. Product only has to be announced, not released. Given product cycle (supposedly 18-24 months; similar to what Moore’s law used to be), dependence on software, Google getting into act (creating own Lidar for Waymo), and upcoming 48V cars (Lidar requires more energy further beam goes/returns ), 400m threshold will be breached with time. Not sure by January, but possible.

Outside view seems to suggest release around May 2019 (18 months since last release). [1] inside view suggests the opposite:
- this rep says they meet all industry requirements in terms of performance. [2] CTO agrees. [3]
- CEO says biggest challenge is software. [4]
- This CTO statement also does not support range improvements as far as I can tell: "Some of the areas of innovation coming up will be additional Lidar sensors that provide enhanced safety for drivers assistance and autonomy applications and software that offers superior processing and integration of Lidar data." [3]
- Not sure what to make of this comment: "Yes, we will get a new LiDAR with 400m range but that takes much more energy and data capabilities that we have available to build marketable vehicles.  In short the answer is yes the technology is there, but to be able to bring it to maket until other technologies like energy and data can provide support. Base on new software developments and battery improvements we can see a processor running the 400m that is marketable in 24-36 months." [5] (FWIW 0% seems wildly overconfident) Overall judgment: I will give more credence to inside view here. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/833063
[2] https://www.autonomousvehicleinternational.com/features/avt-expo-interview-why-lidar-technology-is-the-way-forward.html
[3] https://www.just-auto.com/interview/ces-velodyne-cto-on-lidar-solutions-for-autonomy-and-driver-assistance_id186372.aspx
[4] https://velodynelidar.com/newsroom/velodyne-setting-the-pace-in-lidar-market/
[5] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/835113

Technology evolution cycles are shorter than 2 years.  If the 300 meter version was announced in 2017, you can be sure Velodyne is working on the next version, especially if the 400 meter capability is deemed important to autonomous vehicle success.
Yes but the hardware will not be available for a long while after. If they don't announce it it will cause a huge reduction in investment so they will be pressured to say yes
Most roads are not straight.  Better AI to sort out what is seen is more important.
Given the other applications for this technology the resources allocated could be sufficient to achieve it in the time scale
commercial incentive is there for development
Range is already good enough, the LIDAR makers are concentrating on different targets.
Frankly, there's no need for a LiDAR to look that far unless you're going at unbelievably high speeds. They would do better to make the LiDAR smaller and less of an eyesore.
LiDAR tech is useful in many fields and will likely reach this milestone quickly.

Yes, we will get a new LiDAR  with 400m range but that takes much more energy and data capabilities that we have available to build marketable vehicles. 
In short the answer is yes the technology is there, but to be able to bring it to maket until other technologies like energy and data can provide support. 
Base on new software developments and battery improvements we can see a processor running the 400m that is marketable in 24-36 months.
Did some more reading...and going down to 35% (from 65%). The beam has to get back so requires much more energy/sensitivity etc the further out it goes. Also acknowledging @Joe-Psotka
No, I think they will release closer to the spring.
Lidars are limited by eye safety issues (power) and computation and design (coding) .  The coding curve is very flat so the possibilities of improvement are very limited.

Having a look at Wikipedia [1]  and some other Google search [2] (I had no idea that something called LiDAR existed), I can see a trend in range improvement: - Puck (range 100m) announced November 2014 - not the first one to reach this range though
- Ultra Puck (range 200m) announced April 2016
- Alpha Puck (range 300m) announced November 2017 January 1st 2020 would be within timeframe for a new +100m increase in range. If possible and desired. There is a large number of companies and start-ups (mentioned about 70 [3]) working on making LiDAR better and cheaper, but it seems a lot of focus is in cheaper ([2, 4]). Also, I found this interesting: "Some experts believe the key to building lidar that costs hundreds of dollars instead of thousands is to abandon Velodyne's mechanical design—where a laser physically spins around 360 degrees, several times per second—in favor of a solid-state design that has few if any moving parts. That could make the units simpler, cheaper, and much easier to mass-produce." [2]. Other companies are using alternative technologies, like Innoviz [5] with range up to 250m, Luminar [6] further than 200m, and Quanergy [7] 100m, other sources cited 200m [8] (source [2]). From [2]:
"[...] that's significant because experts believe that fully self-driving cars will need lidar capable of detecting objects 200 to 300 meters away.
Jim McBride, a Ford executive who organized a team for the 2005 DARPA Grand Challenge, explained why in a September interview with Ars.
McBride said to imagine a self-driving car that wants to merge into traffic moving at highway speeds. "Traffic is moving probably 60 miles per hour, roughly 30 meters a second," McBride told Ars. "Most cars will take 6 to 10 seconds to get up to highway speed." So a car will want to be able to see cars that are 6 to 10 seconds—or 180 to 300 meters—away." The question is specifically referring to Velodyne, so my  guess is that the company's strategy in this increasingly competitive market with different alternatives is about reducing cost to an affordable price [4] AND better performance. We have to consider this as a longer term goal though (75%). So, is it technologically possible? 99% YES
Is it a game stopper for the industry? It would add a comparative advantage to gain clients, so 100% YES
Is it strategic for Velodyne's? Not top priority probably, but YES 75%
Is it in the question's timeframe? Say 95% YES. I assume technology improvement when there is a economic motivation. Total 71% 
Too long a comment, sorry. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Velodyne_LiDAR
[2] https://arstechnica.com/cars/2018/01/driving-around-without-a-driver-lidar-technology-explained/
[3] https://techcrunch.com/2019/03/09/transportation-weekly-waymo-unleashes-laser-bear-bird-spreads-its-wings-lyft-tightens-its-belt/
[4] https://techcrunch.com/2017/10/10/velodyne-quadruples-lidar-production-to-meet-self-driving-demand/
[5] https://innoviz.tech/innovizonetest/
[6] https://www.luminartech.com/technology/index.html
[7] https://quanergy.com/s3-qi/
[8] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quanergy

If they want to be the OEM partner of choice, it has to be there. Even 400 m is quite modest for cars travelling at 40 mph or more. The stopping distance at 40 mph for a car is 36m, going up to just under 100m at 70 mph, but that's stopping before you hit a stationary object in front of you, not the closing speed. If you have two lanes of traffic both at 70 mph, the closing speed between them is 140 mph. Also, cars are relatively light and have shorter stopping distances than trucks etc., and if conditions are wet or icy, distances can  double or treble. 400m starts to look like a bare minimum for general use and I'm sure the leading company wants to stay leading..
